Dear Mr. ___,

I hope this letter finds you well as you transition back home after your recent hospitalization. I am writing to provide you with a summary of your hospital stay and to outline your discharge plan and follow-up care.

You were admitted to our hospital on March 1, 2024, with complaints of severe chest pain that radiated to your left arm, accompanied by shortness of breath. Following an initial assessment and diagnostic tests, including an electrocardiogram (ECG), you were diagnosed with an acute transmural myocardial infarction of the anterior wall (ST-elevation myocardial infarction, or STEMI).

Upon admission, you underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) accompanied by stent placement to restore blood flow in your coronary arteries. The procedure was successful, and you were stable post-intervention. Initial laboratory tests on admission revealed elevated troponin levels, indicative of myocardial injury, which began to decrease over the subsequent days. Your complete blood count (CBC) was within normal limits, although your lipid profile showed elevated LDL cholesterol.

During your stay, you were managed with medications including Aspirin 325 mg once daily, Clopidogrel 75 mg once daily, a continuous infusion of IV Heparin, and Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg as needed for chest pain. Starting on March 2, 2024, you were also prescribed Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily, Lisinopril 10 mg once daily, and a Statin 40 mg once daily as part of your ongoing cardiac care.

Daily ward rounds confirmed your stable condition without recurrent chest pain. By March 3, 2024, significant clinical improvement was noted, and discharge planning, including your rehabilitation regimen, began. You received thorough education on your medication regimen during your stay.

As part of your discharge plans, you were provided with discharge instructions and scheduled for follow-up care. You are to attend a cardiology outpatient clinic on March 20, 2024, to evaluate your recovery and manage your medications. It is essential that you adhere to the prescribed lifestyle modifications, including adopting a heart-healthy diet, gradually reintroducing physical activity starting with light walking, immediate cessation of smoking, and engaging in stress management techniques.

If you experience any new or worsening symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, or other concerning symptoms, please seek immediate medical attention.

I wish you a smooth recovery and encourage you to contact our office should you have any questions or concerns regarding your health or follow-up care.

Kind regards,

Dr. ___  
Attending Physician
